newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian call quiet, yields on securities stay firm.
newsitem.headline: Indian call quiet, yields on securities stay firm.

text.p: Indian call money rates were quoted at 0.10-0.50 percent on reporting Friday, dealers said. Three-day money was quoted at 6.0-7.0 percent, they said.
"There was very little activity in call, with only small volume transactions three-day money," a primary dealer said.
He said repo transactions were done for three day period at 6.0-7.0 percent. Call rates are expected to open around 10 percent on Saturday, the first day of the new fortnight.

A dealer at Dil Vikas Finance said there were some trades in tax-free and taxable bonds. The total trades on the National Stock Exchange amounted to 1.25 billion rupees on Friday against Thursday's 2.20 billion, he said.
The 13.62 percent 1998 stock was traded at a yield of 13.30 percent, unchanged from Thursday's levels. The zero-coupon 2000 was traded at 13.92 percent against 13.88 percent, dealers said.

Treasury bills were active, with October 1997 bill traded at 12.65 percent, which is in tandem with it's Reserve Bank auctioned yield. The November 1996 treasury bill was traded at 8.80 percent and the December 1996 treasury bill was traded at 10.23 percent, dealers said.

There were no transactions in commercial papers and certificates of deposit (CD), but P1+ rated companies were trying to place their CDs at 12.50 percent. Inter-corporate deposit rates were steady in the 18-20 percent range for top-rated companies.
